body:
Weber was born in Darmstadt, Germany and immigrated to Philadelphia, PA in 1853 with his parents.

His father, also named Carl, was a musician and a music teacher. His uncle was German artist Paul

Weber who had also immigrated to Philadelphia a little earlier, who had a son also named Carl. Cousin

Carl was also an artist, which had led to some confusion as to which "Carl" painted a particular painting.

"Carl Philipp", is known primarily for his luminist landscape paintings in oil, whereas, "Carl" is known

primarily for his water color paintings. As a young man, Carl Philipp returned to Germany where he

studied under August Von Kreling, noted sculptor and muralist, and also under his uncle Paul who had

returned to Germany permanently circa 1860. Carl Philipp returned to Philadelphia in 1874 where he

lived with his father however, by the late 1800s he had established a studio at 1134 Arch Street. He

painted the scenic vistas of the Adirondack Mountains, including Lake George and the Hudson River

Valley. He was a member of the Artists Fund Society and the Boston Art Club, where he also exhibited.

Carl Philipp also exhibited at the National Academy of Design, the Art Institute of Chicago and the

Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. His paintings have won awards internationallyÃ¢ÂÂLondon,

England, and Sidney and Melbourne, Australia.
dimensions: Oil on canvas, 9.5 x 15.5 inches / Signed lower left

title: Sunset at the Lake
